sentence: Wall Street struggled to continue its winning ways on Thursday as gains driven by earnings news were constrained by more political turmoil in Washington, D.C, and weakness in retailers.
The Nasdaq Composite finished stronger with a new record high on support from pharmaceuticals, but with a slimmer advance than earlier in the week.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was slightly weaker as a 4.1% drop in Home Depot ( HD ) was enough to pressure the overall index, even as nearly two thirds of the 30 components were stronger.
The S&P 500, which closed at a record high a day earlier, ended fractionally in the red.

Markets started the day stronger but a sharp drop came early the session after Bloomberg reported that Robert Mueller, the special counsel looking into possible links between Donald Trump's presidential campaign and Russia, is probing Trump's businesses and those of his associates.

The Russia probe has captured much attention in recent months, with investors concerned that the turmoil is serving as a distraction for Trump's administration and making it difficult for him to push ahead with his policy agenda.
Retailers were dented by news that Sears Holdings ( SHLD ) will sell its Kenmore brand appliances on Amazon.com ( AMZN ).
Lowe's ( LOW ) dropped 5.6%, Whirlpool ( WHR ) shed 4.4% and Home Depot retreated 4.1%.
In earnings, Alliance Data Systems (ADS) fell 9.5% after saying Q2 earnings beat estimates, but it lowered its 2017 guidance.
Qualcomm (QCOM) shed 5% after posting a sharp year-over-year decline in Q3.
BB&T rose 3.4% after Q2 earnings topped the Street view, although revenues were just shy.
KB Financial (KB) added 1.6% after posting strong quarterly results.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(-) SND (-13.34%) Credit Suisse cuts to neutral from outperform, slashes price target to $8.50 from $20
